results.headline: A Christian Avenger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Priest

results.summary_short: “Priest” is Scott Stewart’s second-consecutive film starring Paul Bettany as a John Wayne-like Christian avenger.

results.headline: Hip-Hop for Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go For It!

results.summary_short: Carmen Marron’s “Go for It!,” starring Aimee Garcia, is a briskly edited dance-out-of-the-slums story that speaks to working-class young women.

results.headline: Sun, Sand and Sexual Tension

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vacation!

results.summary_short: Four college girlfriends hit a North Carolina beach in “Vacation!”

results.headline: More Than Abracadabra

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Make Believe

results.summary_short: “Make Believe” follows teenagers competing at an international magic contest in Las Vegas.

results.headline: Deflating That Big, Puffy White Gown

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridesmaids

results.summary_short: “Bridesmaids” celebrates the giddy, liberating humor of the writers Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo.

results.headline: A Taste for Psychedelics and the God Particle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Bang

results.summary_short: “The Big Bang” carries film noir parody into particle physics territory to try to solve the mystery to end all mysteries.

results.headline: Boisterous, Big-Voiced and Built to Last

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Topp Twins: Untouchable Girls

results.summary_short: Leanne Pooley’s film looks at the phenomenon of the Topps, country-singing lesbian twins from New Zealand.

results.headline: Simple Quest for Literacy Hits a Wall of Politics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The First Grader

results.summary_short: Kimani Ng’ang’a Maruge, a member of the Kikuyu tribe in Kenya who enrolled in a primary school in 2003, at age 84, became an inspiration and a lightning rod.

results.headline: Small-Town Nostalgia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skateland

results.summary_short: In “Skateland,” Shiloh Fernández is a teenager whose world of El Caminos, vinyl records and Jordache jeans breaks apart.

results.headline: The Passions and Demons of Yves Saint Laurent

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of L' Amour Fou

results.summary_short: “L’Amour Fou,” a documentary about Yves Saint Laurent, the French couturier, narrated by Pierre Bergé, his partner in business and in life.

results.headline: Only a Number

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Live Forever

results.summary_short: Mark S. Wexler’s documentary visits with a variety of the old and older who just keep on running, working and even making pornographic films.

results.headline: Inside an Influential Novel
results.display_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee & To Kill A Mockingbird

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hey, Boo: Harper Lee & To Kill A Mockingbird

results.summary_short: Mary McDonagh Murphy’s documentary tells how “To Kill a Mockingbird” was written and how it influenced America.

results.headline: Burn This, Curse That, Wreak Your Havoc

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hesher

results.summary_short: Spencer Susser’s “Hesher” stars Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a tattooed, profanity-spewing, heavy-metal life force. And guess what? He has lessons to teach.

results.headline: A Picture Window on a Life Turned Inside Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything Must Go

results.summary_short: “Everything Must Go” adapts and fills in the blanks of the Raymond Carver story “Why Don’t You Dance?”

results.headline: Shooting for the Stars
results.display_title: Cameraman: The Life and Work of Jack Cardiff

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cameraman: The Life and Work of Jack Cardiff

results.summary_short: The Oscar-winning career of Jack Cardiff, a cinematographer for the Archers and others, covered almost a century of the movies.

results.headline: Torture or Porn? No Need to Choose

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Serbian Film

results.summary_short: “A Serbian Film,” directed by Srdjan Spasojevic, doesn’t just push the envelope of the extreme-cinema niche, it shreds it.

results.headline: A Tale of Nanjing Atrocities That Spares No Brutal Detail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of City of Life and Death

results.summary_short: “City of Life and Death” portrays the hundreds of thousands of soldiers and civilians tortured and killed during the mass butchery known as the Rape of Nanjing.

results.headline: The Difference a Baby Can Make

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of October

results.summary_short: “Octubre,” a Peruvian film, shows how life changes for a shabby moneylender in Lima when an infant is left on his bed.

results.headline: The Life of a Searcher

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lord Byron

results.summary_short: Paul Batiste stars in this “Lord Byron,” which was made for less than $1,000.

results.headline: The Family That Stays Together Frays Together

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harvest

results.summary_short: Robert Loggia stars as the dying patriarch of a Connecticut clan in “Harvest,” a meticulously written and exquisitely acted film.
